page.title: 1982 British Army Gazelle friendly fire incident

revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}}{{Coord|51|47|0.96|S|58|28|4.03|W|region:FK_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = Loss of Gazelle XX377 |partof = the [[Falklands War]] |image = GazelleAH1 Ahlhorn May1983.jpeg |image_size = 300px |alt=A small camouflaged helicopter hovers, just off the ground, over a field. |caption = A British Army [[Aérospatiale Gazelle|Gazelle]] helicopter, circa 1983 |date = 6 June 1982 |place = [[Pleasant Peak]], [[Falkland Islands]] |result = Four British soldiers killed,
One [[British Army]] helicopter destroyed }} {{Falklands War}} On 6 June 1982, during the [[Falklands War]], the British Royal Navy Type 42 destroyer {{HMS|Cardiff|D108|6}} engaged and destroyed a British Army Gazelle helicopter, [[United Kingdom military aircraft serials|serial number]] ''XX377'', in a [[friendly fire]] incident, killing all four occupants. ''Cardiff'', on the lookout for aircraft flying supplies to the Argentine forces occupying the [[Falkland Islands]], had misidentified the helicopter as an enemy [[C-130 Hercules]]. Although the helicopter's loss was initially blamed on enemy action, a subsequent inquiry found ''Cardiff''{{'}}s missile to be the cause. On the night of 5 June, HMS ''Cardiff'' was stationed to the east of the islands to provide gunfire support to the land forces and intercept enemy aircraft. At around 02:00 a radar contact was detected; a British [[Army Air Corps (United Kingdom)|Army Air Corps]] [[Aérospatiale Gazelle|Gazelle]] helicopter was making a routine delivery of personnel and equipment to a radio rebroadcast station on [[East Falkland]]. From the contact's speed and course, ''Cardiff''{{'}}s operations room crew assumed it to be hostile. One [[Sea Dart missile|Sea Dart]] missile was fired, destroying the target. The Gazelle's wreckage and crew were discovered the next morning, and the loss was attributed to enemy fire. Although ''Cardiff'' was suspected, later scientific tests on the wreckage proved inconclusive. No formal inquiry was held until four years later. Defending their claim that the helicopter had been lost in action, the United Kingdom's [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] (MoD) stated that they had not wanted to "cause further anguish to relatives" while they were still trying to ascertain how the Gazelle had been shot down. The board of inquiry finally confirmed that the soldiers fell due to friendly fire. It recommended that "neither negligence nor blame should be attributed to any individual", but identified several factors. A lack of communication between the army and the navy meant that [[5th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|5th Infantry Brigade]] had not notified anyone of the helicopter's flight. The navy had not informed the land forces that ''Cardiff'' had changed position to set up an ambush for Argentine aircraft travelling over the area. The helicopter's [[identification friend or foe]] (IFF) transmitter was turned off, because it caused interference with the army's [[Rapier (missile)|Rapier]] anti-aircraft missile system. The board of inquiry's findings prompted criticism of the MoD's initial response to the incident. == Background == On 2 April 1982, the [[British overseas territory]] of the [[Falkland Islands]] was invaded by neighbouring Argentina. The United Kingdom, nearly {{convert|8000|mi|km}} away, assembled and dispatched [[Events leading to the Falklands War#Task force|a naval task force of 28,000 troops]] to recapture the islands. The conflict ended that June with the [[Argentine surrender in the Falklands War|surrender of the Argentine forces]]; the battles fought on land, at sea, and in the air had cost the lives of some 900 British and Argentine servicemen. In early May, British troops landed at [[San Carlos, Falkland Islands|San Carlos]] on the western side of [[East Falkland]], and from there moved overland towards the islands' capital of [[Stanley, Falkland Islands|Stanley]]. To support the advance, logistical supplies were ferried to the troops by helicopter from San Carlos. The Argentine forces occupying Stanley were supplied throughout the war by [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 Hercules]] aircraft from the Argentine mainland. These "milk-runs", as the British termed them, were a source of concern to the Royal Navy, and various attempts were made to intercept them. == Incident == [[File:Aftermath Cardiff NGS.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.2|alt=A large cannon on the front of a warship surrounded by empty shells; waves are breaking over the ship.|Cartridge cases from Cardiff's [[4.5 inch Mark 8 naval gun|4.5 inch gun]] litter her deck after providing gunfire support on 5 June.]] On the night of 5 June, the British Type 42 destroyer {{HMS|Cardiff|D108|6}} took up station on the "Bluff Cove Gunline" to the east of the islands. Tasked with a dual mission, ''Cardiff'' was to provide [[naval gunfire support|fire support]] to the Royal Marines of [[3 Commando Brigade]], and to interdict any Argentine aircraft attempting to fly into Stanley. The destroyer had performed a similar role four nights previously, when she unsuccessfully attempted to shoot down a re-supply aircraft as it landed, and again as it took off.{{cite web |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1987/feb/02/lcpl-s-j-cockton |title=L/Cpl. S. J. Cockton |work=[[Hansard]] |publisher=Parliament of the United Kingdom |date=2 February 1987 |accessdate=19 November 2008}} Meanwhile, pilots [[Staff Sergeant#United Kingdom|Staff Sergeant]] Christopher Griffin and [[Lance Corporal#United Kingdom|Lance Corporal]] Simon Cockton, of [[No. 656 Squadron AAC|656 Squadron]] Army Air Corps, had been ordered to fly equipment and personnel to a malfunctioning radio re-broadcast station on top of [[Pleasant Peak]]. The station had been established the previous day to provide a communications link between the [[5th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|5th Infantry Brigade]] headquarters at [[Darwin, Falkland Islands|Darwin]], and the [[2nd Battalion, Parachute Regiment]] at [[Fitzroy, Falkland Islands|Fitzroy]]. Night flying conditions were excellent, with a clear sky, a prominent moon and a wind speed of {{convert|20|kn|km/h|abbr=on|lk=in}}. The crew departed from [[Goose Green]] in Gazelle [[United Kingdom military aircraft serials|serial number]] ''XX377'' and collected the replacement equipment from the headquarters at Darwin. They also took on board two passengers; [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] Michael Forge, the [[Officer Commanding|OC]] of [[205 Signal Squadron]], and A Tp Staff Sergeant, Staff Sergeant John Baker. Griffin was an experienced pilot; the flight to the re-broadcast station was expected to take ten minutes. [[File:HMS Cardiff (D108) Operations Room.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.3|alt=A sailor in a blue shirt sits at a console, it has a large circular screen and switches.|Cardiff's [[surface plot]] console]] At 02:00 local time, ''Cardiff''{{'}}s [[operations room]] detected ''XX377'' on her [[surface plot]] radar at a range of {{convert|25|nmi|km|lk=in}}. The helicopter's [[identification friend or foe]] (IFF) system was turned off, so receiving no friendly transmissions and with the contact apparently heading towards Stanley, the operations room crew assumed it to be hostile. After calculating its speed they believed they were tracking an Argentine [[fixed-wing aircraft]]—either a Hercules conducting a resupply mission, or a [[FMA IA 58 Pucará]] ground-attack aircraft sent to retaliate for ''Cardiff''{{'}}s shelling. ''Cardiff'' fired one of her [[Sea Dart missile]]s. 5th Infantry Brigade lost radio contact with the Gazelle, and simultaneously the exploding missile was seen and heard by the re-broadcast station's personnel atop Pleasant Peak. ''Cardiff''{{'}}s crew were able to see the fireball, but only with the aid of [[night vision goggles]]. The helicopter's loss caused the British to suspect that Argentine forces were still operating in the area, so patrols were mounted by [[Brigade of Gurkhas|Gurkha]] soldiers. When the Gurkhas came across the personnel manning the Pleasant Peak station there was potential for another friendly fire incident to occur. At first light a proper search was carried out, and the Gazelle's wreckage was found along with the dead aircrew and passengers; 5th Infantry Brigade's first casualties of the war. Immediately there were suspicions that ''Cardiff'' had been responsible for the shootdown, and later that evening Rear Admiral [[Sandy Woodward|"Sandy" Woodward]] declared a "[[Weapons Tight]]" order, forbidding the engagement of any aircraft not positively identified as hostile, for all contacts detected flying over East Falkland at less than {{convert|200|kn|km/h|abbr=on}} and under {{convert|610|m|ft|abbr=on}}. == Investigations == [[File:Sea Dart missile HMS Cardiff 1982.JPG|thumb|left|upright=.8|alt=A large white missile sits on its launcher at the front of a warship.|A live [[Sea Dart missile]] on HMS Cardiff in 1982]] The crew's bodies were initially examined by senior [[Physician|medical officer]], [[Rick Jolly|Surgeon-Captain Richard "Rick" Jolly]] of the [[Royal Navy]]. The helicopter's wreckage was inspected on-site, but the British were unable to determine if it had been destroyed by ''Cardiff''{{'}}s missiles or by Argentine fire. This uncertainty prompted the decision not to hold a board of inquiry, and ''XX377'' was declared "lost in action". It was surmised that, if the relatives of the deceased were told that the Gazelle might have been lost to [[friendly fire]], it would add to their grief. After the war, missile fragments found in the wreckage were taken to the British government's aviation research facility at [[Royal Aircraft Establishment|RAE]] [[Farnborough Airport|Farnborough]] for analysis. The scientific tests concluded that the fragments were not from a British Sea Dart missile, despite a Sea Dart casing later being found "several hundred yards" away from the wreckage. In December 1982 an inquest was held by a [[Southampton]] coroner into the death of Lance Corporal Cockton after his body was repatriated to the UK. Based on RAE Farnborough's test results, the Army Air Corps submitted evidence stating that the analysis of the warhead fragments found in the wreckage indicated that the helicopter had been destroyed by a type of anti-aircraft missile "known to have been in the possession of the enemy". The test results were reviewed in November 1985 and determined that there could be "no definitive conclusion as to the exact source of the missile fragments recovered from the crash site". In June 1986, [[John Stanley (MP for Tonbridge and Malling)|John Stanley]], the [[Minister of State for the Armed Forces]], announced in his written answers to the House of Commons: "the [Southampton] coroner has been informed accordingly." [[File:HMS Cardiff Sea Dart Launcher.JPG|thumb|upright=.8|alt=An empty missile launcher on the front of a warship, it has scorch marks on it. In the background there are empty shell casings.|Cardiff's scorched missile launcher the morning after the shootdown]] In October 1986, partly due to pressure from Cockton's mother and the anti-war politician [[Tam Dalyell]], an official board of inquiry was finally opened. The board took a month to reach the conclusion that ''XX377'' was shot down by ''Cardiff''. Historian [[Hugh Bicheno]] remarks: "It took [the] MoD four years and two investigations, the first either incompetent or a deliberate cover-up, even to admit the Gazelle [[friendly fire|blue-on-blue]]." The board's findings were made public by a [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information Act]] request in July 2008, although Paragraph 13 of the report was [[Sanitization (classified information)|redacted]] under Section 26 of the act as it "contains operational details of the Royal Navy's activities, which, even with the passage of time since the Falklands campaign, would be of use to potential enemies." The board of inquiry found that standard operating procedure dictated that the commanders of 5th Infantry Brigade were not required to declare the helicopter's mission to any other authority, as the flight was to occur in brigade airspace on a brigade task. Gazelle ''XX377'' was equipped with an IFF transmitter, but this was turned off. In the opinion of the board, "had IFF been in use there is little doubt that Cardiff would not have engaged the aircraft that night." At the time, less than half of the land force's helicopters were fitted with IFF transmitters, and those that were had been ordered not to use them because they inhibited the tracking systems of the British ground-based [[Rapier (missile)|Rapier]] anti-aircraft missile batteries. A misconception about the Royal Navy's ability to engage air targets over land led to the navy not being informed that the army's helicopters were not using IFF. The board of inquiry concluded that it was this failure to communicate, together with the navy's assumption that all helicopters would be operating IFF, which "had a cumulative effect [and] was a major cause of [the] accident." However, the board recommended that "neither negligence nor blame should be attributed to any individual". == Effects == [[File:XX377Memorial2.JPG|thumb|alt=A cross amongst rocks painted white and a mountain in the background|The memorial cross]] Given that the role of helicopters in land force operations was increasing, as was the integration of [[guided missile destroyer]]s for coastal defence, the board of inquiry recommended an amendment to [[NATO]] procedures for [[amphibious warfare]] and [[naval gunfire support]], to alert other armed forces to the danger of underestimating a ship's missile engagement zone over land. During the late 1980s, the British government placed more emphasis on [[joint warfare]] training, with exercises, such as [[Exercise Purple Warrior|Purple Warrior]], taking place in [[Oman]] and Scotland. The board noted the establishment of the [[Permanent Joint Headquarters]], designed to put an end to the "ad hoc and reactive way" in which operations had been carried out while under single service control. IFF transmitters were fitted to all Army Air Corps and Royal Marine Gazelle and [[Westland Lynx|Lynx]] helicopters, and the problem of operating IFF in the vicinity of [[Rapier (missile)|Rapier]] batteries was successfully addressed. The board supported a recommendation that the responsibilities of naval gunfire-support liaison officers could be broadened to include the interpretation of air defence problems during inshore joint warfare operations. A memorial cross was installed on Pleasant Peak, and the number "205" was painted at the crash site by the soldiers of 205 Signal Squadron. The number is approximately {{convert|40|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide and can be seen from the air ({{Coord|-51.783600|-58.467786}}). ==See also== *[[List of accidents and incidents involving military aircraft (1980–89)]] == References == {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/EF248AAE-5B25-4CB4-BE90-EE096980354B/0/boi_loss_gazellexx377.pdf |format=PDF |title=Board of inquiry into the loss of AAC Gazelle XX377 |author=Navy Command HQ |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] |accessdate=19 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081125053424/http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/EF248AAE-5B25-4CB4-BE90-EE096980354B/0/boi_loss_gazellexx377.pdf |archivedate=25 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=}} {{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/guides/457000/457033/html/default.stm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308095608/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/guides/457000/457033/html/default.stm |archivedate=8 March 2008 |title=Key facts: The Falklands War, Introduction |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 March 2008}} {{cite web|url=http://hmscardiff.co.uk/rop.aspx |title=Report of Proceedings |publisher=hmscardiff.co.uk |accessdate=12 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526055504/http://hmscardiff.co.uk/rop.aspx |archivedate=26 May 2008 |df=}} {{cite web |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1986/jun/25/falkland-islands-gazelle-helicopter |title=Falkland Islands |work=[[Hansard]] |publisher=Parliament of the United Kingdom |date=25 June 1986 |accessdate=19 November 2008}} {{cite book |authorlink=Lawrence Freedman |last=Freedman |first=Lawrence |title=The Official History of the Falklands Campaign. {{Infobox Magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | category = [[News magazine]] | editor = Arturo Navarro (1976–1978) | editor_title = Director | frequency = Weekly | circulation = | company = | publisher = | firstdate = June 1976 | lastdate = 1995 | country = [[Chile]] | based = [[Santiago]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | website = | issn = 0716-1212 }} '''''APSI''''' (an abbreviation of "Agencia Publicitaria de Servicios Informativos") was a Chilean [[magazine]] aimed as means of [[political opposition]] to the [[Military dictatorship of Chile (1973–90)|Pinochet dictatorship]]. It was headquartered in Santiago.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://search.library.wisc.edu/catalog/999608034802121|title=APSI : actualidad nacional e internacional|work=University of Madison Wisconsin Library|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=September 2018}}
== History ==
One of the tactics of the dictatorship was to isolate the public from international news and outside influences in order to maintain its stranglehold on information. Following the 1975 shutdown of the human rights organization {{ill|Comité Pro Paz|es}} in response to a political offensive by the Pinochet regime, Precht, then Vicar, allowed the ex-employees to issue grant requests to European commissions. One of the European applications was a project to create a news agency about international news. This request by Arturo Navarro,<!-- Not [[Arturo Navarro]], Spanish football player--> an ex-Comité employee, resulted in a grant of seven thousand dollars, and APSI was born.<ref name="Jofré-2007">{{cite book |author=Francisca Araya Jofré |title=Historia de la revista Apsi: el que se ríe se va al cuartel (pico para Pinochet) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IrRHQBZ31ysC&pg=PA20 |series=Nuevo Periodismo |year=2007 |publisher=Lom Ediciones |location=Santiago |isbn=978-956-282-944-1 |oclc=1026152018 |pages=20<!--to 24--> |accessdate=19 September 2018}}</ref>
APSI was published on a weekly basis.<ref>{{cite news|author=David Remnick|title=To die in Chile|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/magazine/1986/11/23/to-die-in-chile/7b87938b-0ecf-4410-bbca-050e2f77c33a/|accessdate=15 November 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=23 November 1986}}</ref> Due to the climate of censorship in Chile the magazine focused initially on international news. ''APSI'' was published with support of the [[Popular Unitary Action Movement]] until late 1978. In 1979 the magazine begun reporting on local issues including the numerous human rights violations of the dictatorship.<ref name=mem>{{Cite web|url=http://www.memoriachilena.cl/602/w3-article-96757.html|title=APSI|website=Memoria Chilena|publisher=Biblioteca Nacional de Chile|language=es|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231053749/http://www.memoriachilena.cl/602/w3-article-727.html|archivedate=31 December 2013|deadurl= no}}</ref>

Acedapsone, or 1399 F, is a diacetyl compound, derived from [[dapsone]]. It was synthesized and developed in 1937 by [[Ernest Fourneau]] and his team in the pharmaceutical chemistry laboratory of [[Pasteur Institute]],{{fr icon}} E. Fourneau, J. et Th. [[Jacques Tréfouël|Tréfouël]], [[Federico Nitti|F. Nitti]], [[Daniel Bovet|D. Bovet]], « Chimiothérapie de l'infection pneumococcique par la di-(p-acétylaminophényl)-sulfone (1399 F) », ''C. r. Acad. sci''., vol. 205, 1937, pp. 299-300. and it was marketed as Rodilone by the [[Rhône-Poulenc]] company.{{fr icon}} [[Marcel Delépine]], ''Ernest Fourneau (1872–1949) : Sa vie et son œuvre'', extrait du Bulletin de la Société chimique de France, Masson et Cie, 1950, pp. 64-67. It is a long-acting [[prodrug]] of dapsone. It is used for treating [[leprosy]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Shaw IN, Christian M, Jesudasan K, Kurian N, Rao GS |title=Effectiveness of multidrug therapy in multibacillary leprosy: a long-term follow-up of 34 multibacillary leprosy patients treated with multidrug regimens till skin smear negativity |journal=Lepr Rev |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=141–7 |date=June 2003 |pmid=12862255 |doi= |url=}} It crystallises as pale yellow needles from [[diethyl ether]], and as leaflets from dilute [[ethanol]]. It is slightly soluble in water. == Synthesis == [[File:Acedapsone synthesis.svg|thumb|center|500px|Acedapsone synthesis:{{Cite journal|doi=10.1021/jm00303a003|pmid=4892242|title=Repository drugs. W.|last2=Clemence|first2=L. W.|last3=Severac|first3=M.|last4=Moetsch|first4=J. C.}}{{Cite journal|doi=10.1002/cber.190804102131|title=Derivate desp-Nitrothiophenols|journal=Berichte der deutschen chemischen Gesellschaft|volume=41|issue=2|pages=2264|year=1908|last1=Fromm|first1=E.|last2=Wittmann|first2=J.}}]] Acedapsone is conveniently prepared by acetylation of dapsone. == References == {{reflist}} {{Antimycobacterials}} [[Category:Sulfones]] [[Category:Withdrawn drugs]] {{antimicrobial-stub}}

{{about|bear pits in general}} [[Image:Bernbarengraben.jpg|thumb|right|Bears in the ''Bärengraben'' in [[Bern]] (Switzerland)]] A '''bear pit''' was historically used to display [[bear]]s, typically for entertainment and especially [[bear-baiting]]. The pit area was normally surrounded by a high fence, above which the spectators would look down on the bears.
The most traditional form of maintaining [[bear]]s in [[captivity (animal)|captivity]] is keeping them in pits, although many zoos replaced these by more elaborate and spacious enclosures that attempt to replicate their natural [[Habitat (ecology)|habitat]]s, for the benefit of the [[animal]]s and the visitors.
A noteworthy example is found in [[Bern]], [[Switzerland]]. Known as the ''[[Bärengraben]]'', it was built in 1857 and is still in use though much modified.
== Other meanings ==
Another meaning is for an unusually aggressive political arena, in which direct, heated attacks are common.<ref name="BANKSHERALD">''[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10536851 What happened to bully Banks?]'' - ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'', Saturday 11 October 2008</ref>
A bear pit also refers to a type of trap used to deter or trap bears. It usually consists of a large earthen pit with sharpened pikes in the bottom to impale the bear. They are most often used to deter bears from approaching a cabin, rather than as a means of actually catching them.
The term "bear pit" is also used to describe a [[tournament]] or sparring format sometimes also referred to as "[[King of the Hill (game)|king of the hill]]". The participants form a queue behind the first two to compete. Once each match is over, the winner remains to face the next opponent in line while the loser goes to the end of the queue. For tournaments, it is usual that the process is continued for a set period of time during which the victor of each match is noted. At the end of the tournament the winner is determined to be the contestant that won the most matches. Multiple bear pits may also be employed, with defeated contestants able to choose which queue to re-enter.
In Scotland, the phrase "Bear pit" is used to describe bars or public houses that are known to have a violent reputation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dictionary of the Scots Language - Bearpit|url=http://www.dsl.ac.uk/entry/snd/sndns275}}</ref>

[[Image:bodelwyddan castle view2 arp.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Bodelwyddan Castle]] '''Bodelwyddan Castle''' ({{lang-cy|Castell Bodelwyddan}}) , close to the village of [[Bodelwyddan]], near [[Rhyl]], [[Denbighshire]] in [[Wales]], was built around 1460 by the Humphreys family of [[Anglesey]] as a [[manor house]]. Its most important association was with the [[Williams-Wynn baronets|Williams-Wynn]] family, which extended for around 200 years from 1690. It is now a Grade II* [[Listed Building]] and is open to the public as a [[historic house museum]].''Caring for Our Built Heritage: Conservation in Practice''; Tony Haskell, 1993, p.133 ==History== [[File:Bodelwyddan house.jpg|thumb|Watercolour of the house that preceded Bodelwyddan Castle c1781]] The [[castle]] was bought from the Humphreys by [[William Williams (speaker)|Sir William Williams]], [[Speaker of the British House of Commons|Speaker]] in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] from 1680–1681.{{cite web| url=http://www.npg.org.uk/live/bodintro.asp| archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20010305204359/http://www.npg.org.uk/live/bodintro.asp| dead-url=yes| archive-date=2001-03-05| title=Bodelwyddan Castle Introduction| work=National Portrait Gallery| accessdate=2007-12-01}} [[Image:Bodelwyddan Castle2.jpg|thumb|left|Bodelwyddan Castle]] The castle which stands today was reconstructed between 1830 and 1832 by [[Sir John Hay Williams]], who employed the architects [[Joseph Hansom]] (inventor of the [[Hansom cab]]) and [[Edward Welch]] to refurbish and extend the house.Harris, Penelope,''The Architectural Achievement of Joseph Aloysius Hansom (1803–1882)'', The Edwin Mellen Press, 2010, {{ISBN|0-7734-3851-3}}. The Williams' family fortunes started to decline in the 1850s, due to the loss of the main source of income for the estate, [[lead#Lead_mining_in_Wales|lead mining]]. The castle has been described as one of Hansom's most ambitious projects, "being wildly dramatic and owing nothing to its predecessors".Tony Haskell, ''Ibid.'', p.133 At the same time works were carried out to construct an estate wall and formal gardens. Further refurbishment work was carried out in the 1880s by [[Sir Herbert Williams-Wynn, 7th Baronet|Sir Herbert, 7th Baronet]], who inherited Bodelwyddan Castle from his heirless cousin.By the [[First World War]] the house had become a recuperation hospital for wounded soldiers. During this time, the grounds of the estate were used by soldiers based at the nearby [[Kinmel Camp]] for [[trench warfare]] training.{{cite web |url=http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/ww1trenches.html |title=Trenches |work=Bodelwyddan Castle |accessdate=2007-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613163726/http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/ww1trenches.html |archivedate=2010-06-13 |df= }} Traces of these trenches can still be seen. ===Lowther College=== By 1920, the cost of maintaining the castle and estate had grown too burdensome, and the Williams-Wynn family leased Bodelwyddan to [[Lowther College]], a girls private school. The school was formed in 1896 at [[Lytham St. Annes]] in [[Lancashire]], by Mrs [[Florence Lindley|Florence Morris]] (later [[Florence Lindley|Lindley]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.nlw.org.uk/cgi-bin/anw/fulldesc_nofr?inst_id=28&coll_id=2188&expand= |title=Lowther College |work=Archives Network Wales |accessdate=2007-12-01 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Lowther College purchased the property five years later, in 1925. The school is thought to be one of the first private schools for girls to have its own swimming pool. It also had a private golf course. The Lowther College Tableaux were well regarded within the community for their musical excellence. Boys were admitted from 1977. The school closed in 1982 due to financial problems.{{cite web|url=http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/college.htm |title=Lowther College |work=Bodelwyddan Castle |accessdate=2007-12-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108180315/http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/college.htm |archivedate=2007-11-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===Museum and arts centre=== In the 1980s, the site was bought by [[Clwyd]] [[County Council]] with the aim of developing the castle as a visitor attraction. Partnerships were formed with the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)|National Portrait Gallery]] and the [[Royal Academy of Arts]], so that the castle could be used to display objects from these collections. In order to house these items, the interior of the castle was restored by [[Roderick Gradidge]], an expert on [[Victorian architecture]]. Part of the site was leased to the [[Rank Organisation]] in 1994 for development into a luxury hotel, Bodelwyddan Castle Hotel,{{cite web|url=http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/history.htm |title=History |work=Bodelwyddan Castle |accessdate=2007-12-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108180159/http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/history.htm |archivedate=2007-11-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and is now run by Warners, who are part of the [[Bourne Leisure]]. The historic house and grounds are not part of the hotel but are managed by '''Bodelwyddan Castle Trust''', an independent registered charity,{{EW charity|1040969|BODELWYDDAN CASTLE TRUST}} and are open to the public. The castle's association with the National Portrait Gallery came to an end in 2017 after its funding was cut by [[Denbighshire County Council]].{{Citation|URL=http://www.museumsassociation.org/museums-journal/news/15022017-funding-cut-forces-bodelwyddan-castle-to-end-loan-agreement-with-the-national-portrait-gallery?dm_i=2VBX,EVVJ,27LY3L,1IWTJ,1|first=Eleanor|last=Mills|date=15 March 2017|title=Bodelwyddan Castle to sever ties with National Portrait Gallery|publisher=[[Museums Association]]|accessdate=16 March 2017}} ==Gardens== The castle is set within a large area of parkland, and formal gardens, the most recent of which was originally designed by [[Thomas Hayton Mawson]] in 1910.{{cite web|url=http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/gardens.htm |title=gardens |work=Bodelwyddan Castle |accessdate=2007-12-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108180029/http://www.bodelwyddan-castle.co.uk/gardens.htm |archivedate=2007-11-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Bodelwyddan Castle Gallery==

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{NSA surveillance|2}} '''Boundless Informant''' (stylized as '''BOUNDLESSINFORMANT''') is a [[big data]] analysis and [[data visualization]] tool used by the United States [[National Security Agency]] (NSA). It gives NSA managers summaries of the NSA's worldwide data collection activities by counting [[metadata]].<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|author=Glenn Greenwald and Ewen MacAskill |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/08/nsa-boundless-informant-global-datamining |title=Boundless Informant: the NSA's secret tool to track global surveillance data |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |location=London |date=June 8, 2013}}</ref> The existence of this tool was disclosed by documents leaked by [[Edward Snowden]], who worked at the NSA for the [[defense contractor]] [[Booz Allen Hamilton]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Edward Snowden: the whistleblower behind revelations of NSA surveillance|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-surveillance |accessdate=June 9, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=June 9, 2013|location=London|first1=Glenn|last1=Greenwald|first2=Ewen|last2=MacAskill|first3=Laura|last3=Poitras}}</ref> Those disclosed documents were in a direct contradiction to the NSA's assurance to [[United States Congress]] that it does not collect any type of data on millions of Americans.<ref>{{cite news|title=Here's The NSA's Supposedly Non-Existent Tool To Track Global Metadata |url=http://gawker.com/heres-the-nsas-supposedly-non-existent-tool-to-track-512177941 |accessdate=March 20, 2014 |newspaper=Gawker |date=June 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320215856/http://gawker.com/heres-the-nsas-supposedly-non-existent-tool-to-track-512177941 |archivedate=March 20, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref>
== History == Intelligence gathered by the United States government inside the United States or specifically targeting US citizens is legally required to be gathered in compliance with the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] of 1978 (FISA) and under the authority of the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]] (FISA court).<ref name="Dean1">Dean, John W. [http://writ.corporate.findlaw.com/dean/20051230.html George W. Bush as the New Richard M. Nixon: Both Wiretapped Illegally, and Impeachable; Both Claimed That a President May Violate Congress' Laws to Protect National Security], FindLaw, December 30, 2005</ref><ref name="Holtzman1">[http://www.thenation.com/doc/20060130/holtzman The Impeachment of George W. Bush] by [[Elizabeth Holtzman]], [[The Nation]], January 11, 2006</ref><ref name="ABA1">[http://www.abanet.org/op/greco/memos/aba_house302-0206.pdf Adopted By The House Of Delegates] ([https://www.webcitation.org/6IhTquVmP?url=http://apps.americanbar.org/op/greco/memos/aba_house302-0206.pdf Archive]), [[American Bar Association]], February 13, 2006</ref>
NSA global data mining projects have existed for decades, but recent programs of intelligence gathering and analysis that include data gathered from inside the United States such as [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] were enabled by changes to US surveillance law introduced under [[Presidency of George W. Bush|President Bush]] and renewed under President Obama in December 2012.<ref name=Greenwald1>{{cite news|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|title=NSA taps in to internet giants' systems to mine user data, secret files reveal|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/us-tech-giants-nsa-data |accessdate=June 6, 2013|date=June 6, 2013|location=London}}</ref>
Boundless Informant was first publicly revealed on June 8, 2013, after classified documents about the program were leaked to ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/boundless-informant |title=Boundless Informant | World news |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |location=London |date=June 8, 2013}}</ref> This report contained a [[Top Secret]] [[heat map]] produced by the Boundless Informant program summarizing data records from 504 separate DNR and DNI collection sources or [[SIGAD]]s. In the map, countries that are under surveillance are assigned a color from green to red (which does not correspond to intensity of surveillance).<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/08/nsa-boundless-informant-data-mining-slides |title=Boundless Informant NSA data-mining tool – four key slides |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |location=London |date=June 8, 2013}}</ref><ref name="The Blaze, Inc">{{cite web|url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2013/06/07/11-questions-you-probably-have-about-u-s-domestic-spying-answered/ |title= Government: 11 things you need to know about u.s. domestic spying |publisher=The Blaze, Inc. |date=June 7, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Boundless-heatmap-large-0001.png|thumb|center|844px|The worldwide heat map from the NSA's data visualisation tool BOUNDLESSINFORMANT, showing that during a 30-day period, 97 billion internet data records (DNI) and 124 billion telephony data records (DNR) were collected.]]
As this map shows that almost 3 billion data elements from inside the United States were captured by the NSA over a 30-day period ending in March 2013, Snowden stated that this tool was collecting more information on Americans located within the United States than on Russians in Russia.<ref name=GellmanVictory>[[Barton Gellman|Gellman, Barton]]. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/edward-snowden-after-months-of-nsa-revelations-says-his-missions-accomplished/2013/12/23/49fc36de-6c1c-11e3-a523-fe73f0ff6b8d_story.html Edward Snowden, after months of NSA revelations, says his mission’s accomplished]." ''[[Washington Post]]''. December 23, 2013. Retrieved on February 7, 2014.</ref> Snowden stated that he raised concerns with two superiors in the Hawaii regional base of the NSA Threat Operations Center and two superiors in the Technology Directorate of the NSA beginning in October 2012, and therefore that counted as using internal dissent channels in the NSA.<ref name=GellmanVictory/>
Snowden added that coworkers often were "astonished to learn" about this detail and did not wish to know any more about the program, and that until April 2012 he often asked these colleagues "What do you think the public would do if this was on the front page?"<ref name=GellmanVictory/> Vanee Vines, an NSA spokesperson, stated that "After extensive investigation, including interviews with his former NSA supervisors and co-workers, we have not found any evidence to support Mr. Snowden's contention that he brought these matters to anyone's attention."<ref name=GellmanVictory/>
The first publication about Boundless Informant was followed by screenshots from this program showing charts with details about the data that NSA allegedly collected from several European countries between December 10, 2012 and January 8, 2013. These charts were published by a major news outlet from each of these countries:
[[File:Boundless Informant Screencap, Germany.jpg|thumb|350px|Screenshot from the BOUNDLESSINFORMANT tool, showing charts with different details about data collection related to Germany. The upper chart shows internet (blue bars) and telephony (green bars) data, the bottom center chart mentions two [[SIGAD]]s and the most important "tech" in the bottom right section is the [[XKeyscore]] program.]] * July 29, 2013: '''Germany''': a big chart about this country, showing more than 552 million telephony and internet data, alongside four smaller charts about The Netherlands, France, Spain and Italy were published by the magazine ''Der Spiegel''.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-105648237.html Daten aus Deutschland], August 5, 2013</ref> * October 20, 2013: '''France''': a chart showing almost 70 million telephony metadata was published by the newspaper ''Le Monde''. * October 28, 2013: '''Spain''': a chart showing 60 million telephony metadata was published by the newspaper ''El Mundo''.<ref>Glenn Greenwald & German Aranda, [http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2013/10/28/526dcbad61fd3d07678b456b.html La NSA espió 60 millones de llamadas en España en sólo un mes], October 28, 2013</ref> * November 19, 2013: '''Norway''': a chart showing 33 million telephony metadata was published by the tabloid paper ''Dagbladet''.<ref>Glenn Greenwald & Arne Halvorsen, [http://www.dagbladet.no/2013/11/19/nyheter/pluss/samfunn/politikk/utenriks/30383890/ USA overvåket 33 millioner norske mobilsamtaler], November 19, 2013</ref> * December 6, 2013: '''Italy''': a chart showing almost 46 million telephony metadata was published by the tabloid paper ''L'Espresso''.<ref>Glenn Greenwald & Stefania Maurizi, [http://espresso.repubblica.it/inchieste/2013/12/05/news/da-qui-ci-spiano-gli-americani-1.144421 Da qui ci spiano gli americani], December 6, 2013.</ref> * February 8, 2014: '''The Netherlands''': a chart showing 1.8 million telephony metadata was published by the newspaper ''NRC Handelsblad''.<ref>Top Level Telecommunications, [http://electrospaces.blogspot.nl/2014/02/boundlessinformant-metadata-collection.html BOUNDLESSINFORMANT: metadata collection by Dutch MIVD instead of NSA], February 8, 2014</ref>
Initially, these media wrote that the BoundlessInformant charts showed how much phonecalls NSA intercepted from a particular country. A first correction of this interpretation is that the program doesn't count the content of phone calls, but only the metadata thereof (see [[#Technology|below]]).
A second correction is about by whom and where these data were collected. On August 5, a week after the publication of a chart from BoundlessInformant in Germany, the German intelligence agency [[Bundesnachrichtendienst|BND]] said that they collected these data from foreign communications, related to military operations abroad.<ref>Der Spiegel, [http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/german-intelligence-sends-massive-amounts-of-data-to-the-nsa-a-914821.html Mass Data: Transfers from Germany Aid US Surveillance], August 5, 2013</ref><ref>Marcel Rosenbach & Holger Stark, Der NSA Komplex, Deutsche Verlags-Anstalt, München 2014, p. 235 and 326.</ref> A similar statement was made by the Norwegian military intelligence service, after a chart about Norway was published on November 19.<ref>RT.com, [http://rt.com/news/norway-nsa-snowden-spying-us-965/ Norway admits it carried out phone surveillance for NSA], November 19, 2013.</ref> On February 4, 2014, the Dutch government revealed that the 1.8 million metadata in the chart about the Netherlands were not collected by NSA, but instead by the Dutch military intelligence service [[MIVD]], also to support military operations, which almost led to the resignation of the Dutch interior minister.<ref>Top Level Telecommunications, [http://electrospaces.blogspot.nl/2014/02/dutch-government-tried-to-hide-truth.html Dutch government tried to hide the truth about metadata collection], February 17, 2014</ref>
On October 29, 2013, NSA-director [[Keith B. Alexander]] declared that accusations in French, Spanish and Italian media about NSA intercepting millions of phone calls from these countries are "completely false". He added that "This is not information that we collected on European citizens. It represents information that we and our NATO allies have collected in defense of our countries and in support of military operations."<ref>Reuters.com, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/29/us-usa-security-nsa-idUSBRE99S03N20131029 NSA chief defends agency amid U.S. spy rift with Europe], October 29, 2013</ref>
== Technology == Although the initial reports in European media stated that the various charts presented the numbers of phone calls intercepted by NSA, a powerpoint presentation and a [[Frequently Asked Questions|FAQ]] document published by ''The Guardian''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/08/boundless-informant-nsa-full-text |title=Boundless Informant: NSA explainer – full document text |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |location=London |date=June 8, 2013}}</ref> say that BoundlessInformant is counting and analysing DNI (internet) and DNR (telephony) [[metadata]] records passing through the NSA's [[signals intelligence]] systems, and are therefore not showing how much content of internet and telephone communications is intercepted.<ref>Top Level Telecommunications, [http://electrospaces.blogspot.com/2013/10/boundlessinformant-only-shows-metadata.html BOUNDLESSINFORMANT only shows metadata], October 22, 2013.</ref>
Data analyzed by Boundless Informant includes [[Computer surveillance|electronic surveillance program]] records and [[pen register|telephone call metadata]] records stored in an NSA data archive called GM-PLACE. It does not include [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act|FISA]] data, according to the FAQ memo. [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], a government codename for a collection effort known officially as US-984XN, which was revealed at the same time as Boundless Informant, is one source of DNR data.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/><ref name="The Blaze, Inc"/>
According to published slides, Boundless Informant leverages [[Free and Open Source Software]]—and is therefore "available to all NSA developers"—and corporate services hosted in the [[Cloud Computing|cloud]]. The tool uses [[HDFS]], [[MapReduce]], and [[Apache Accumulo|Accumulo]] (formerly Cloudbase)<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/wiredenterprise/2012/07/nsa-accumulo-google-bigtable/ |title=NSA Mimics Google, Pisses Off Senate, Cade Metz |work=Wired |date= July 17, 2012}}</ref> for data processing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/710559-doc01187820130608104742.html#document/p4 |title=Boundless Informant slides |publisher=Documentcloud.org |accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} [[File:Bowling Green Massacre Survivor.jpg|thumb|upright|A protester in [[London]] on February 4, 2017]]
The '''Bowling Green massacre''' is a [[fiction|fictitious]] incident alluded to by U.S. [[Counselor to the President]] [[Kellyanne Conway]] in interviews with ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' and [[TMZ]] on January 29, 2017 and in an interview on the [[MSNBC]] news program ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'' on February 2, 2017. Conway cited it as justification for [[Executive Order 13769|a travel and immigration ban]] from seven Muslim-majority countries enacted by [[President of the United States|United States President]] [[Donald Trump]]. However, no such massacre occurred. The day after the interview, Conway said she misspoke and had been referring to the 2011 arrest of two Iraqi refugees in [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]], on charges including "attempting to provide material support to terrorists and to [[al-Qaeda in Iraq]]".<ref name=fbi2011/> She stated that she had mentioned the incident because it led President [[Barack Obama]] to tighten immigration procedures for Iraqi citizens.
Her false statement went [[Viral phenomenon|viral]] and became the top trending topic on [[Twitter]], with many tweets parodying it. A website was set up anonymously for the purpose of collecting donations for supposed victims. [[Facebook]] users used the site's [[Facebook Safety Check|safety check feature]] to act as if the event were real. Mock vigils were held in Kentucky and New York in commemoration. It provoked widespread press reaction, with many relating it to Conway's earlier use of the phrase ''[[alternative facts]]'' to describe false statements by [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Sean Spicer]] in the wake of the [[inauguration of Donald Trump]].
==Background== ===Terrorism-related arrests in Bowling Green=== [[File:Fountain Square Park, Bowling Green, Kentucky.JPG|thumb|Bowling Green, Kentucky, the target in Conway's "massacre" statement]]
In 2011, two Iraqi men who had entered the country as refugees were arrested in Bowling Green, Kentucky, on federal terrorism charges after they attempted to send both money and weapons to al-Qaeda in Iraq.<ref name=fbi2011/><ref name="washpo" /><ref name="NYT Coscarelli">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/03/us/politics/bowling-green-massacre-kellyanne-conway.html |title=Kellyanne Conway Admits 'Bowling Green massacre' Error |last=Coscarelli |first=Joe |date=February 3, 2017 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> Both were convicted of supporting attacks on the U.S. military while they were still in Iraq as well as attempting to provide material support to al-Qaeda in Iraq after they emigrated to the United States.<ref name="NYT Coscarelli" /> Arrests were made on various charges, including "attempting to provide material support to terrorists and to al Qaeda in Iraq".<ref name=fbi2011>{{cite press release |publisher=U.S. Department of Justice |title=Federal Bureau of Investigation |url=https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/louisville/press-releases/2011/two-iraqi-nationals-indicted-on-federal-terrorism-charges-in-kentucky |accessdate=February 8, 2017 |language=English |date=May 31, 2011}}</ref>
Before entering the U.S., both had used [[improvised explosive device]]s in Iraq,<ref name="OPA">{{cite press release |author=[[Office of Public Affairs]] |title=Former Iraqi Terrorists Living in Kentucky Sentenced for Terrorist Activities |url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/former-iraqi-terrorists-living-kentucky-sentenced-terrorist-activities |date=January 29, 2013 |publisher=[[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] |accessdate=February 3, 2017}}</ref> although this was not known at the time of their admission. Both pleaded guilty; one is serving a life sentence while the other is serving 40 years in [[Federal prisons in the United States|federal prison]].<ref name="NYT Coscarelli" /> The two did not attack anyone in the U.S.,{{r|washpo}} and there was no evidence that the men traveled back to Iraq or had any contact with the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] after being admitted to the U.S. Neither was charged with plotting attacks inside the United States.<ref name="OPA"/>
In response to the arrests, the [[administration of Barack Obama]] re-vetted 58,000 refugees already in the country, imposed vetting on 25,000 other Iraqi citizens still in Iraq, and significantly tightened the processing of Iraqi visa and refugee applications for six months.<ref name="CNN Willingham"/> Obama also instituted a requirement for new background checks on visa applicants from Iraq; as a result, Iraq travel visas were issued more slowly.<ref name="WBKO Social media">{{Cite news |url=http://www.wbko.com/content/news/412673973.html |title=Social media firestorm over Conway's Bowling Green massacre" comments |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=WBKO ABC 13 |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> The changes in visa verification were temporary, and some Iraqi refugees continued to be admitted to the United States throughout the period.<ref name="CNN Willingham" />
===Similar possible misstatements=== In September 2014, on ''[[Fox News Sunday]]'', [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Peter T. King|Peter King]] of New York referred to the 2011 arrest of Iraqi nationals in Kentucky as an attempt to "attack either [[Fort Campbell]] or [[Fort Knox]]".<ref name="MSNBC Benen">{{Cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/the-fort-knox-plot-only-peter-king-could-see |title=The Fort Knox plot that only Peter King could see |last=Benen |first=Steve |date=September 24, 2014 |publisher=MSNBC |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> The fact-checking site [[PolitiFact.com]], which evaluated the statement as being false, found that he had said something similar at least seven times previously.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Steve |last=Contorno |url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2014/sep/23/peter-king/rep-peter-king-says-isis-tried-attack-fort-knox-20/ |title=Rep. Peter King says Islamic State tried to attack Fort Knox in 2011 |publisher=PolitiFact.com |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref>
On January 29–30, 2017, [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Sean Spicer]] stated that Islamist terrorists perpetrated a terrorist attack in [[Atlanta]], even though Atlanta has never had a terrorist attack carried out by Islamists. The initial comment was made on ABC's ''This Week'', and then Spicer repeated the claim on MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'' the following day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/02/08/sean-spicer-makes-up-atlanta-islamist-attack.html |title=Sean Spicer Makes Up Atlanta Islamist Terror Attack |first=Patricia |last=Murphy |date=February 8, 2017 |publisher= |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> Spicer later said that he meant Orlando, referring to the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]], which was carried out by U.S.–born [[Omar Mateen]]. There have been two terrorist attacks in Atlanta: the 1996 [[Centennial Olympic Park bombing]], which was carried by domestic terrorist Eric Rudolph, and the 1958 [[Hebrew Benevolent Congregation Temple bombing]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Claiborne |first1=Matthew |title=Sean Spicer on Citing Atlanta Terror Attack That Never Happened: I 'Clearly Meant' Orlando |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/sean-spicer-citing-unknown-atlanta-terror-attack-times/story?id=45364173 |accessdate=February 21, 2017 |work=ABC News |date=February 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://politics.blog.ajc.com/2017/02/08/remember-the-atlanta-massacre-yeah-that-didnt-happen-either/ |title=Your Daily Jolt: The Atlanta massacre never happened, either – Political Insider blog |first1=Greg |last1=Bluestein |first2=Tamar |last2=Hallerman |first3=Jim |last3=Galloway |publisher= |accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref>
A day later, on January 31, two days before the ''Hardball'' interview with Conway, Kentucky senator [[Rand Paul]] referenced the 2011 case in an interview with MSNBC by mentioning "the possibility or the attempted bombing in Bowling Green, Kentucky, where I live". ''The Washington Post{{'s}}'' Fact Checker noted that Paul's statement was truer than Conway's because the Iraqi nationals did discuss bombing an Army target in the United States, even though neither was charged with making actual plans to do so.<ref name="washpo" /><ref name="guardian 2017-02-03"/>
==False statements by Conway== [[File:Kellyanne Conway by Gage Skidmore 3.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Kellyanne Conway]] in 2017]]
On January 29, 2017, in an interview with ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'', Conway said that Obama had limited Iraqi immigration because "two Iraqi nationals came to this country, joined ISIS, traveled back to the Middle East to get trained and refine their terrorism skills, and come back here, and were the masterminds behind the Bowling Green massacre of taking innocent soldiers' lives away".<ref name="Cosmo" >{{cite news |url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/a8674035/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-massacre-repeat/ |title=That MSNBC Interview Was Not the First Time Kellyanne Conway Referred to the 'Bowling Green Massacre' |last=Mascia |first=Kristen |date=February 6, 2017 |work=Cosmopolitan |accessdate=February 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Guardian_Smith">{{Cite news |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=February 6, 2017 |first=David |last=Smith |title=Kellyanne Conway's fictitious 'Bowling Green massacre' not a one-time slip of the tongue |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/06/kellyanne-conway-fake-bowling-green-massacre-three-times}}</ref>
On the same day, in a brief interview with [[TMZ]], Conway stated: "He did that because, I assume, there were two Iraqis who came here, got radicalized, joined ISIS, and then were the masterminds behind the Bowling Green attack on our brave soldiers."<ref name="Beast_TMZ">{{cite news |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/02/06/kellyanne-conway-referenced-bowling-green-attack-in-tmz-interview.html |title=Kellyanne Conway Referenced 'Bowling Green Attack' in TMZ Interview |last=Resnick |first=Gideon |date=February 6, 2017 |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |accessdate=February 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Guardian_Smith" />
Three days later, on February 2, in an interview with [[Chris Matthews]] on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'', Conway described the "Bowling Green massacre" as an attack of [[terrorism]] carried out within the United States by [[refugee]]s.<ref name="NPR Chappell">{{Cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/03/513222852/bogus-bowling-green-massacre-claim-snarls-trump-adviser-conway |title=Bogus 'Bowling Green Massacre' Claim Snarls Trump Adviser Conway |last=Chappell |first=Bill |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=NPR |access-date=February 2, 2017}}</ref> Conway said:
{{quote|I bet, there was very little coverage {{nsmdns}} I bet it's brand new information to people that President Obama had a six-month ban on the Iraqi refugee program after two Iraqis came here to this country, were radicalized {{nsmdns}} and they were the masterminds behind the Bowling Green massacre. I mean, most people don't know that because it didn't get covered.<ref name="NPR Chappell"/><ref name="guardian 2017-02-03">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/03/kellyanne-conway-refugees-bowling-green-massacre-never-happened |title=Kellyanne Conway blames refugees for 'Bowling Green massacre' that never happened |last=Phipps |first=Claire |date=February 3, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>}}
Although the interviews with ''Cosmopolitan'' and TMZ were conducted first, they did not become public until after the MSNBC interview aired.
==Aftermath== On February 3, the day after her MSNBC interview, Conway said she misspoke and that she meant to use the term "Bowling Green terrorists" instead of "Bowling Green massacre",<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://time.com/4659303/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-massacre-donald-trump/ |title=Twitter Mocks Kellyanne Conway's False 'Bowling Green Massacre' Comments |last=Rahim |first=Zamira |date=February 3, 2017 |work=Time |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> referring to the two Iraqi men arrested in 2011.<ref name="washpo" /> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' subsequently mentioned previous statements by Conway where she had made reference to the nonexistent massacre, indicating that "she doesn't appear to have misspoken at all".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/02/06/kellyanne-conways-bowling-green-massacre-wasnt-a-slip-of-the-tongue-shes-said-it-before/ |first=Aaron |last=Blake |title=Kellyanne Conway's 'Bowling Green massacre' wasn't a slip of the tongue. She has said it before |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 6, 2017 |accessdate=February 7, 2017}}</ref>
Conway's statement that the men became "radicalized" in the United States was found to be incorrect, as they had been radicalized outside of the country.<ref name="Cosmo" /> Conway's statement that President Obama "had a six-month ban on the Iraqi refugee program" was misleading, as the Obama administration move was not a formal ban.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gajanan |first1=Mahita |title=Kellyanne Conway Has Claimed There's Been a 'Bowling Green Massacre' More than Once |url=http://fortune.com/2017/02/06/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-massacare/ |accessdate=February 22, 2017 |work=Fortune |date=February 6, 2017}}</ref> Contrary to Conway's claims, there is no evidence that the men had traveled back to the Middle East<ref name="Cosmo" /> or had any contact with ISIS after being admitted to the United States.{{Citation needed|reason=Needs a source that actually says whether the men had any contact with ISIS. |date=February 2017}} Neither of the two was ever charged with plotting attacks inside the United States.<ref name="CNN Willingham">{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/03/politics/bowling-green-not-massacre-terrorists-trnd/ |title=Here's what actually happened in Bowling Green |last=Willingham |first=AJ |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=CNN |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref>
Conway, in her February 3 statement, said that there was no coverage of the Bowling Green investigation, which she intended to refer to.<ref name="Wash Post Schmidt">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/02/03/kellyanne-conway-cites-bowling-green-massacre-that-never-happened-to-defend-travel-ban/ |title=Kellyanne Conway cites 'Bowling Green massacre' that never happened to defend travel ban |last=Schmidt |first=Samantha |date=February 3, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> However, there were approximately 90 news articles that covered the arrest and charges at the time.<ref name="Wash Post Schmidt" /> Conway's February 3 statement cited an example of that coverage, without acknowledging that her claim that "it didn't get covered" was also incorrect.<ref name="NYT Coscarelli" />
On February 5, CNN declined an interview with Conway, partly because of "serious questions about her credibility" and partly because CNN could not get [[Mike Pence]], whom the administration made available to all the other major Sunday shows.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/05/business/the-massacre-that-wasnt-and-a-turning-point-for-fake-news.html |title=The Massacre That Wasn't, and a Turning Point for 'Fake News' |first=Jim |last=Rutenberg |work=The New York Times |date=February 5, 2017 |accessdate=February 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="politico" /> That day, she said in a text exchange, "Frankly they were terrorists in Bowling Green but their massacre took place in Iraq."<ref name="Cosmo" /> Two days later, she was a guest on CNN, interviewed on air by [[Jake Tapper]]. In the interview, Conway apologized for repeatedly referencing a "Bowling Green massacre" that did not happen.<ref name="politico">{{cite web |last1=Quigley |first1=Aidan |work=[[Politico]] |title=Conway: CNN is not 'fake news' |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/02/kellyanne-conway-cnn-interview-234760 |accessdate=February 7, 2017 |date=February 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Stedman |first1=Alex |title=Kellyanne Conway Apologizes for Bowling Green 'Massacre' Remark, Spars With CNN's Jake Tapper |url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-massacre-cnn-jake-tapper-1201980910/ |accessdate=February 8, 2017 |work=Variety |date=February 7, 2017 |quote="I regretted it tremendously because I used the wrong word to describe something several times", she went on. "I felt badly about that and I apologize and I rectify."}}</ref>
In a March 2017 interview with ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'', Conway said she intended to say "Bowling Green masterminds" rather than "Bowling Green massacre", in reference to "would-be terrorists who were apprehended before they staged an attack".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nuzzi|first1=Olivia|title=Kellyanne Conway Is a Star Not your star, perhaps. But that's the point.|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/03/kellyanne-conway-trumps-first-lady.html|website=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''|accessdate=March 24, 2017|date=March 17, 2017}}</ref>
==Reactions== [[File:NoBanNoWall SF 20170204-1721 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Man holding satirical sign at protest in [[San Francisco]], February 2017]]
The video clip of Conway's "massacre" statement went [[Viral phenomenon|viral]] online,<ref name="NYT Coscarelli" /> with the phrase becoming the top trending topic on Twitter.<ref name="Wash Post Schmidt" /><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2017/02/03/kellyanne-conway-references-fake-bowling-green-massacre-defend-refugee-ban/97436868/ |title=Kellyanne Conway on 'Bowling Green massacre': I meant 'terrorists' |last=Sayers |first=Justin |date=February 3, 2017 |work=The Courier-Journal |location=Louisville, Kentucky |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> Some Twitter users wrote that, despite Conway's clarification, substituting "terrorists" for "massacre" in her statement did not make sense.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/02/trump-aide-mocked-bowling-green-massacre-lie-170203150255194.html |title=Trump aide mocked after 'Bowling Green massacre' lie |last= |first= |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=Al Jazeera |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> Her statement was parodied on Twitter and other platforms with people creating fake tributes.<ref name="NPR Chappell" /> A website was set up anonymously for the purpose of collecting donations for victims of the imaginary massacre; the donation link on the website goes to the [[ACLU]]'s donation page.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/site-to-get-donations-for-bowling-green-massacre-victims-fund-launches/ |title=Site To Get Donations for 'Bowling Green Massacre Victims Fund' Launches |last=Ellefson |first=Lindsey |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=Mediaite |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Bowling-Green-Massacre-Victims-Fund-website-links-10906739.php |title='Bowling Green Massacre Victims Fund' website links to ACLU donation page |last=Disbrow |first=Bill |date=February 3, 2017 |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> [[Facebook]] users mocked the Bowling Green massacre by using Facebook's safety check feature to pretend the event was real.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/02/03/facebook-users-pretend-the-bowling-green-massacre-is-real/ |title=Facebook users pretend the 'Bowling Green Massacre' is real |last=Seppala |first=Timothy J. |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=Engadget |access-date=February 4, 2017}}</ref> In [[New York City]]'s [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]], people held a mock vigil to commemorate the "victims" of the "massacre".<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/new-yorkers-hold-vigil-bowling-green-massacre-victims-article-1.2963989 |title=New Yorkers hold vigil at Bowling Green for 'massacre' victims |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |access-date=February 4, 2017}}</ref> Another mock vigil took place on February 3, 2017, in Bowling Green, Kentucky.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/2017/02/03/massacre-jokes-fly-city-known-car-eating-sinkhole/97461276/ |title=Never remember: Bowling Green laughs along at massacre that wasn't |last=Schreiner |first=Bruce |date=February 3, 2017 |access-date=February 4, 2017 |work=The Courier-Journal |location=Louisville, Kentucky}}</ref> Responses on the [[Donald Trump]]-centric [[subreddit]] [[:/r/The Donald]] were "varied – and rather muted", with some [[redditor]]s speculating that it was an intentional part of a larger strategy by the Trump administration.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/opinion/article/Analysis-What-came-after-Conway-s-Bowling-Green-10905848.php |title=Analysis: What came after Conway's 'Bowling Green massacre' statement |last=Bump |first=Philip |date=February 3, 2017 |access-date=February 3, 2017 |work=San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref>
Samantha Schmidt wrote in ''[[The Washington Post]]'': "Conway has taken 'alternative facts' to a new level".<ref name="Wash Post Schmidt" /> ''[[The Atlantic]]'' wrote that her "false statement stands out because it is simultaneously inaccurate and has the potential to be extremely inflammatory".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/02/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-massacre-alternative-facts/515619/ |title=Kellyanne Conway and the Bowling Green Massacre That Wasn't |last=Foran |first=Clare |date=February 3, 2017 |work=The Atlantic |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> [[Brian Stelter]] on [[CNN]] criticized the Trump administration for "hammering" the media for mistakes but going easy on Conway's error.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/02/03/media/kellyanne-conway-trump-errors/ |title=Will Trump give Conway leniency he won't give media? |last=Stelter |first=Brian |date=February 3, 2017 |publisher=CNN |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> British journalist [[Marina Hyde]] wrote a column in ''[[The Guardian]]'' criticizing the [[Trump administration]] for creating a fictional massacre when it was silent on the [[Quebec City mosque shooting]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/feb/03/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-terrorist-attack-trump-team |title=Bowling Green massacre? Kellyanne Conway has taken alt facts up a notch |last=Hyde |first=Marina |date=February 3, 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> UK talk show ''[[The Last Leg]]'s'' [[Alex Brooker]] commented: "Are there so few shootings in America that they're having to make them up?"<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Last Leg |series=Series 10 |episode=Episode 2 |date=February 3, 2017 |url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/the-last-leg}}</ref> ''Cosmopolitan'' reporter Kristen Mascia said: "It didn't surprise me that the comment was premeditated and that she'd tried it on multiple writers (who knows who else she auditioned it with, frankly). But others out there may not know this about her, and they should. We must call out the [White House] for stuff like this because it's egregious and totally unacceptable."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/02/06/media/kellyanne-conway-bowling-green-massacre-cosmopolitan/index.html |title=Kellyanne Conway's "Bowling Green Massacre" wasn't one-time slip-up, Cosmo reveals |last=Stelter |first=Brian |date=February 6, 2017 |website=CNNMoney |access-date=February 7, 2017}}</ref> After [[Chelsea Clinton]] posted a tweet that stated, in part: "Please don't make up attacks",<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=827518183934394370 |user=ChelseaClinton |title=Very grateful no one seriously hurt in the Louvre attack ... or the (completely fake) Bowling Green Massacre. Please don't make up attacks. |first=Chelsea |last=Clinton |date=February 3, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/people_ew/2017/02/kellyanne_conway_under_fire_after_citing_non_existent_bowling_green |title=Kellyanne Conway under fire after citing non-existent 'Bowling Green massacre' to defend refugee ban |date=February 3, 2017 |work=Boston Herald |access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> Conway replied: "Bosnia lie a Great reminder", referring to how Clinton's mother [[Hillary Clinton]] falsely claimed to have landed in Bosnia "under sniper fire" during the [[Bosnian War]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Merica |first1=Dan |title=Chelsea Clinton knocks Kellyanne Conway: 'Please don't make up attacks' |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/03/politics/chelsea-clinton-kellyanne-conway-trump-response/ |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=February 3, 2017}}</ref>
Writing in ''The New York Times'', A.C Thompson mentioned the 2012 case of a man who the authorities suspected of trafficking in counterfeit goods. His home and his store in [[Bowling Green, Ohio]], were raided, and 18 firearms were found in his possession. Federal authorities believed that he was planning on killing African Americans and Jews. The man, who the prosecutors called a white supremacist, pleaded guilty to weapons and counterfeit charges, but prosecutors failed to establish that he was a political terrorist.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thompson |first1=A.C |title=When the Government Really Did Fear a Bowling Green Massacre |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/08/opinion/when-the-government-really-did-fear-a-bowling-green-massacre.html |date=February 8, 2017 |work=The New York Times}}</ref>
The mayor of Bowling Green, Kentucky, issued a statement clarifying that "there was no massacre in Bowling Green", adding that he understood "how during a live interview one can misspeak and we appreciate the clarification".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://origin-nyi.thehill.com/homenews/administration/317784-bowling-green-mayor-understands-people-can-misspeak |title=Bowling Green Mayor 'Understands' People Can Misspeak |last=Hensch |first=Mark |date=February 3, 2017 |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |accessdate=February 4, 2017 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Conway's statement was parodied in two segments of [[Saturday Night Live (season 42)|season 42]] of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. In the [[cold open]] for that season's episode 13, [[Alec Baldwin]], playing the role of Donald Trump, said that in the Bowling Green massacre, "[s]o many people died, but really they're the lucky ones. They don't have to see how bad ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' has gotten".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/02/05/alec-baldwin-returns-as-snls-trump-where-an-evil-stephen-k-bannon-is-actually-president/ |title=Alec Baldwin returns as Trump on SNL, where an evil Bannon is actually president |last=Izadi |first=Elahe |date=February 5, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=February 13, 2017 |work= |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286 |via=}}</ref> In episode 14's cold open, [[Melissa McCarthy]], playing the role of Sean Spicer, recited a list of terrorist incidents that "you [the news media] never even write about",<ref name=":1"> {{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/02/12/melissa-mccarthy-returns-to-snl-as-an-even-more-frustrated-sean-spicer/ |title=Melissa McCarthy returns to SNL as an even more frustrated Sean Spicer |last=Izadi |first=Elahe |date=February 12, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=February 13, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref name="Spicey">{{Cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/12/514800509/melissa-mccarthys-spicey-and-alec-baldwins-trump-return-to-snl|first1=James|last1=Doubek|first2=Maquita|last2=Peters |title=Melissa McCarthy's 'Spicey' And Alec Baldwin's Trump Return To 'SNL' |newspaper=NPR.org |access-date=February 13, 2017 |publisher=[[NPR]] |language=en}}</ref> referencing a list of 78 supposedly under-reported terrorist incidents that the White House had released earlier that week.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/02/07/white-house-78-terror-attacks-list-trump/97582018/ |first1=Kim|last1=Hjelmgaard|title=Media covered most of 78 terror attacks Trump said 'not even being reported' |newspaper=USA TODAY |access-date=February 13, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> McCarthy, as Spicer, said: "The Bowling Green massacre—not the Kellyanne one, the real one. The Horror in [[Six Flags]]. The Slaughter at [[Fraggle Rock]]. [[The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down]]. Okay?!"<ref name=":1" /><ref name="Spicey"/>

{{refimprove|date=January 2011}} '''Builders' rites''' are [[ceremony|ceremonies]] attendant on the laying of [[foundation stone]]s, including [[ecclesiastical]], [[masonic]] or otherwise and other traditions connected with [[foundation (architecture)|foundation]]s or other aspects of construction.
One such custom is that of placing a few coins, newspapers, etc. within a cavity beneath the stone. Should the stone later be removed, the relics may be found. Though this tradition is still practiced, such memorials are deposited in the hope that they will never be disturbed.<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911|inline=1 |wstitle=Builders' Rites |volume=4 |page=762|first=William James |last=Hughan}} According to the above, the best succinct account of these rites was to be obtained in [[George Speth|G. W. Speth]]'s ''Builders' Rites and Ceremonies'' (1893).</ref>
==History== Living victims were once entombed as "a sacrifice to the gods" and to ensure the stability of the building.
[[Jacob Grimm|Grimm]] remarked "It was often thought necessary to immure live animals and even men in the foundation, on which the structure was to be raised, to secure immovable stability."<ref>''Teutonic Mythology'' (1883–1884), (trans. Stalleybrass)</ref> This gruesome practice is well evidenced, in multiple cultures. "The old pagan laid the foundation of his house and fortress in blood."<ref>[[Sabine Baring-Gould|Baring-Gould]] on "Foundations," ''Murray's Mag''. (1887)</ref> Under the walls of two round towers in [[Ireland]] (the only ones examined) human skeletons were discovered. In the 15th century, the wall of [[Holsworthy, Devon|Holsworthy]] church was built over a living human being, and when this became unlawful, images of living beings were substituted.<ref>''Folk-Lore Journal'', i. 23-24</ref><ref name=EB1911/>
References to this practice can be found in Greek folk culture in a poem about "Arta's bridge". According to the poem, the wife of the chief builder was sacrificed to establish a good foundation for a bridge that was of grave importance to the secluded city of Arta. The actual bridge was constructed in 1602. A similar legend appears in the Romanian folk poem ''' [[Meșterul Manole]], ''' about the building of the church in the earliest Wallachian capital city.

{{Infobox television | show_name = Emcee Africa | image = | genre = [[Reality competition]] | runtime = 52 minutes | creator = Jonathan Clarke | presenter = [[Leslie 'Lee' Kasumba]] | executive_producer = | theme_music_composer = Don Juan (Octave Couplet) | country = [[South Africa]] | language = [[American English|English]] | network = [[Channel O]] | picture_format = [[480i]] ([[SDTV]]) {{Small|(2000–2008)}}
[[1080i]] ([[HDTV]]) {{Small|(2008–present)}} | first_aired = {{Start date|2008|5|31}} | last_aired = {{End date|2009|8|31}} | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 26 | related = | website = http://beta.mnetafrica.com/fanclub/?clubId=1078 }} The '''Channel 0 Emcee Africa tour''' is a tour that is sponsored by [[Sprite (soft drink)|Sprite]]. It was associated with '''Emcee Africa - The Battle Chronicles''', a talent show televising the competition. It was a [[continent]]-wide search for the premier freestyle [[MC]]/[[Rapper]]. The tour started in [[Accra, Ghana]], and then went through [[Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania]], [[Nairobi, Kenya]], [[Luanda, Angola]], [[Lagos, Nigeria]] and [[Johannesburg, South Africa]].[http://www.africanhiphop.com/index.php?module=subjects&func=viewpage&pageid=284 Africanhiphop.com :: African Rap :: 10 years online] [[Gaborone]], [[Botswana]] was included in the second season, while [[Luanda, Angola]] and [[Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania]] were cut from the tour. The motive of the tour was not only to find the best freestyle MC, but to initiate [[international]] awareness of the 'street life' surrounding social and cultural context of the localized music. In other words, the tour was attempting to better contextualize the application and reception of [[hip hop]] culture in each visited country. The winner received $10,000, a video and a song deal. ==Format and rules== The first season of ''Emcee Africa'' followed the host [[Leslie 'Lee' Kasumba]] to the various host cities, where the local [[MC]]/[[Rapper]]'s were invited to an audition. The final eight MC's were selected to face off in a knockout competition to determine the winner. During the auditions, each performer had two minutes to prove their candidacy for the final eight to a panel of judges. A topic was given to each contender to Freestyle about in order to ensure each contestant was truly improvising and not using any written material. After eight contestants were selected from each country, a separate contest was held, where the eight members would face off to battle each other in two 30 second parts, divided into 2 rounds, followed by the Final. The winner from each country was then flown into Johannesburg to compete for the "Emcee Africa" title, as well as the grand prize. A judge from each country's panel was then flown in to ensure neutrality in the final competition. The second season followed a similar format with similar rules, except that ten contenders were selected from the auditions, rather than eight. In the second season, contestants who made it through to the second round did not Battle each other but were rather judged based on a performance. From the performance, the judges panel selected two finalists to face off in a final battle. ==Wildcard== For the Final Battle in the first season, audiences could log into www.channelo.co.za, and vote for their favorite [[MC]]/[[Rapper]] from the previous competitions, to reappear in the final stages. ==Host== [[Leslie 'Lee' Kasumba]] (a top hip hop radio [[Disc Jockey|DJ]] from South Africa's YFM station) is the host. She also corresponds for Africanhiphop.com. On the tour called 'the Battle Chronicles', she was chosen to narrate her daily experiences of traveling. ==Quotes== "Never before has a continental Hip Hop reality based competition such as this existed."[http://kamerayangu.blogspot.com/2007/12/channel-o-sprite-emcee-battle.html mkonowangu: CHANNEL O SPRITE EMCEE BATTLE] ==Emcee Africa 1== ===Ghana=== Date: Saturday, 22 December 2007
